sense.name: a distinguished social privilege
sense.examples: It was an honor to finally meet the famous British author. He considered it a great honor to be invited to attend the ceremonies. It is my honor to present our distinguished speaker this evening, Jane Smith.

sense.name: being in a state of exalted recognition
sense.examples: Mary had the honor of being voted Woman of the Year. It's a dubious honor to be chosen to head the entertainment committee of our club. Tom graduated from Harvard with the highest honors. He has received many honors for his humanitarian work.

sense.name: a tangible medal for bravery, exemplary conduct
sense.commentary: HONOR[+artifact][+award][+medal][+for_excellence] Note: implies Sense 2, but Sense 3 refers to the visible artifact symbolizing Sense 2.
sense.examples: They bestowed the highest honor on the soldier for his bravery in battle. This medal is an honor only bestowed on military personnel, not civilians. The wine critic received the highest French honor at a ceremony in Paris.

sense.name: a woman's chastity
sense.examples: She defended her honor against the mustached villain. The knight protected the princess's honor against the evil king.

sense.name: quality of personal moral integrity
sense.examples: He is a man of honor and would not lie or steal. The signers of the Declaration of Independence pledged their lives, their fortunes and their sacred honor to the principles of that document. The politician's honor is in doubt after this scandal.

sense.name: an advanced scholastic course
sense.examples: Sally is taking honors calculus and honors English this year. It's an honors course for advanced students.
